"I couldn't be more excited for Berkeley's next decade and beyond. And what we will build together." –Chancellor Rich Lyons

Rich Lyons has come a long way. First, he was a student, then an alum, and now UC Berkeley's 24th leader. As he assumes his new role, he reflects on the values and principles that serve as the foundation for what's to come.

Thanks to a generous $750,000 gift, the new Paul Alpers Memorial Fund will boost the Doreen B. Townsend Center for the Humanities' fellowship and Art of Writing programs. Pledged by Matt and Margaret Jacobson, the gift honors the founding director of UC Berkeley’s renowned nexus of humanities research and events.

The Townsend Center’s fellowships allow faculty and graduate students to conduct and discuss research with colleagues in other disciplines. The gift will be used to increase graduate student fellows' funding packages, restore a cut faculty fellowship, and provide much-needed funds to various programs.

“It’s very meaningful,” said Stephen Best, the center’s faculty director. “Faculty don’t have as much time in the day to organize symposia and other scholarly events, so this gift gives us real flexibility to provide that service, allowing for interdisciplinary collaboration."

Read more about the new fund and the namesake: https://gobears.me/3ATHeFX

“I know new emotions can seem unhelpful at first, but I've learned that every emotion is a good emotion.” -Joy, Inside Out 2

We may have UC Berkeley psychology professor Dacher Keltner to thank for all of the new emotions in Inside Out 2. Keltner spent much of his early career cataloging and analyzing how emotions, particularly embarrassment, play out across our faces. At Pixar Animation Studios, he's been using his expertise as a scientific advisor on the Inside Out films for over a decade.

When he first talked with Pete Docter, the director of Inside Out, he explained that there are 25 emotions that scientists like him have cataloged. Docter, in turn, explained that you can't possibly have 25 main characters in a film, yet the count is now up to nine as Riley's emotions expand in her teen years.

In this video, Keltner, who has been teaching students about human emotions at UC Berkeley for over 25 years and co-directs The Greater Good Science Center, unpacks the real science behind the Disgust microexpression scene and new characters in the films. 

🔗 Full video on our YouTube: https://lnkd.in/grWXDx6T

Every day someone asks Hany Farid, a UC Berkeley professor in the UC Berkeley School of Information, to review images, audio and videos to determine if they are real or fake. As one of the world’s leading experts on digital manipulation and misinformation, his views and verification skills are in high demand. 

With elections being held around the globe this year, including the presidential election in the United States, he’s been especially busy using digital forensic tools to verify or debunk political misinformation as it spreads in real time, but the rapid advances of AI have only complicated his job.

We asked Professor Farid to sit down with a handful of recent examples of political misinformation to explain how he analyzes questionable memes, social media posts and images. 

🔗 Full video also available on UC Berkeley's Youtube channel: https://lnkd.in/guDeHJ8r

Can enzymes create complex molecules from “scratch?"

In a study published by Nature Chemistry, a team of UC Berkeley researchers at the College of Chemistry led by Wenjun Zhang, Ph.D., reported the discovery of the first natural enzyme capable of creating these complex molecules — azides — from simpler ones.

Azide is a useful chemical group that has many applications in fields like materials science, chemistry, drug discovery, and biology. One of its key uses is in a reaction called the azide-alkyne click reaction, a widely recognized reaction that has enabled many innovations in biology.

The discovery opens up new possibilities for using biological processes to produce azides. Read more: https://lnkd.in/gW-Cw-Eq

Thanks to a $15 million grant from the National Science Foundation (NSF), UC Berkeley, in conjunction with partners at other public universities, aims to bridge the “valley of death” between academia and entrepreneurship. The grant will fund regional trainings and new instructors as well as program expansion and outreach through affiliates, helping broaden the hub’s overall impact.

UC Berkeley will serve as the lead institution for the newly organized NSF Northwest Region Innovation Corps Hub, which includes University of California, Davis, UC Irvine, University of California, San Francisco, University of California, Santa Cruz, Oregon State University, University of Alaska Fairbanks and the University of Washington. Chancellor Lyons noted that as the world’s top producer of venture capital-funded startups founded by undergraduate alumni, Berkeley is perfectly poised for this role.

The ultimate goal, said Shrader, is to unlock the commercial potential of research. Across California and the Northwest, said Rhonda Shrader, the executive director and lead instructor of I-Corps at Berkeley, “It’s going to bring more opportunity, security and prosperity to everyone.”

For the full story, visit #BerkeleyNews: https://lnkd.in/gVsFWA2Y
